texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I replaced my old Toyota 4Runner with a new one so I could snag the last run of the 5th generation. It's a tough, reliable vehicle with just enough space for my family and our pets.
texts.text: I replaced my old Toyota 4Runner with a new one so I could snag the last run of the 5th generation. It's a tough, reliable vehicle with just enough space for my family and our pets.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, this new one came with the same problem as my old one. All of the bolts that hold in the front skid plate were mostly stripped. Getting them out was difficult and I knew getting them back in would be worse.
texts.text: However, this new one came with the same problem as my old one. All of the bolts that hold in the front skid plate were mostly stripped. Getting them out was difficult and I knew getting them back in would be worse.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'll cover how to fix it in this post. If you're in a hurry, scroll past the next section! Otherwise, let's get a little backstory.
texts.text: I'll cover how to fix it in this post. If you're in a hurry, scroll past the next section! Otherwise, let's get a little backstory.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Backstory
texts.text: Backstory

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All  4Runner models  are made in Japan in the  Tahara Plant . The build quality is fantastic and you can tell that they're built with care. You can even find brief notes in Japanese inside the fenders or underneath the car where someone jotted some notes about something.
texts.text: All  4Runner models  are made in Japan in the  Tahara Plant . The build quality is fantastic and you can tell that they're built with care. You can even find brief notes in Japanese inside the fenders or underneath the car where someone jotted some notes about something.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After careful assembly in Japan, they head to various US ports where American workers add on any extra items that come with the trim level. That could include an upgraded exhaust, different wheels, or in my case, skid plates.
texts.text: After careful assembly in Japan, they head to various US ports where American workers add on any extra items that come with the trim level. That could include an upgraded exhaust, different wheels, or in my case, skid plates.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The skid plate is a sturdy piece of steel that mounts under the front of the vehicle and protects lots of important components from damage. You can see it under the front bumper in this photo:
texts.text: The skid plate is a sturdy piece of steel that mounts under the front of the vehicle and protects lots of important components from damage. You can see it under the front bumper in this photo:

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Skid plate on a white 4Runner
texts.text: Skid plate on a white 4Runner

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 4runner-skid.jpg
texts.text: 4runner-skid.jpg

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you've ever owned a Toyota, you know that the factory is strict about torque applied to various bolts all over the vehicle. All of that gets thrown out the window when the workers at the US ports add on accessories.
texts.text: If you've ever owned a Toyota, you know that the factory is strict about torque applied to various bolts all over the vehicle. All of that gets thrown out the window when the workers at the US ports add on accessories.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Based on all the complaints I've seen across various 4Runner forums, they must use air wrenches or some kind of impact wrench to put on the bolts. If the bolt isn't in straight when they start, it destroys the bolt and causes problems with the mount holes. They also tighten the bolts  far past the acceptable torque specs.
texts.text: Based on all the complaints I've seen across various 4Runner forums, they must use air wrenches or some kind of impact wrench to put on the bolts. If the bolt isn't in straight when they start, it destroys the bolt and causes problems with the mount holes. They also tighten the bolts  far past the acceptable torque specs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: To make matters worse, if you take your car in for an oil change at most places,  they'll have an impact wrench handy to ruin the bolts a bit more for you.
texts.text: To make matters worse, if you take your car in for an oil change at most places,  they'll have an impact wrench handy to ruin the bolts a bit more for you.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Root cause
texts.text: Root cause

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you have bolts that are getting stripped in the mount holes or they're getting stuck as you try to bring the bolts in or out, you likely have chunks of metal from the bolts wedged in the threads of the bolt holes.
texts.text: If you have bolts that are getting stripped in the mount holes or they're getting stuck as you try to bring the bolts in or out, you likely have chunks of metal from the bolts wedged in the threads of the bolt holes.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Ingredients
texts.text: Ingredients

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The fix is quite cheap but very tedious. You'll need a few parts to get started:
texts.text: The fix is quite cheap but very tedious. You'll need a few parts to get started:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Irwin Hanson 12002 T-Handle Tap Wrench (1/4" to 1/2")'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Irwin Hanson 12002 T-Handle Tap Wrench (1/4" to 1/2")'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Irwin Tap 10-1 25mm Plug'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Irwin Tap 10-1 25mm Plug'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Toyota part PT938-00140-AA'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Toyota part PT938-00140-AA'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='14mm socket and socket wrench OR a 14mm wrench:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='14mm socket and socket wrench OR a 14mm wrench:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Some type of lubricant.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Some type of lubricant.'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What's hilarious is that if you load the Amazon page for the Toyota part, it shows that everyone is buying tap screws and T-Handle wrenches:
texts.text: What's hilarious is that if you load the Amazon page for the Toyota part, it shows that everyone is buying tap screws and T-Handle wrenches:

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Even Amazon knows these bolts are a problem! 😆
texts.text: Even Amazon knows these bolts are a problem! 😆

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: buy-together.jpg
texts.text: buy-together.jpg

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Fix the bolt holes
texts.text: Fix the bolt holes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First things first, you'll need to get that skid plate off. I strongly recommend taking the rear bolts off first. If the bolts get stuck on the way out, take your time. I found that rocking in the other direction briefly and then trying to loosen them again seemed to work.
texts.text: First things first, you'll need to get that skid plate off. I strongly recommend taking the rear bolts off first. If the bolts get stuck on the way out, take your time. I found that rocking in the other direction briefly and then trying to loosen them again seemed to work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With the rear bolts out, move to the bolts closest to the front of the car. Put a box or something sturdy underneath the skid plate that allows it to drop when it's loose but prevents it from knocking out one of your teeth when it falls. 🤕
texts.text: With the rear bolts out, move to the bolts closest to the front of the car. Put a box or something sturdy underneath the skid plate that allows it to drop when it's loose but prevents it from knocking out one of your teeth when it falls. 🤕

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you loosen the front bolts, try loosening one of them 4-5 turns and then go to the other one. Keep going back and forth loosening the bolts until they loosen from the frame of the car. There are retaining washers on the top side of the bolt and removing those bolts aggressively will slide the retaining washers right off the bolt.
texts.text: When you loosen the front bolts, try loosening one of them 4-5 turns and then go to the other one. Keep going back and forth loosening the bolts until they loosen from the frame of the car. There are retaining washers on the top side of the bolt and removing those bolts aggressively will slide the retaining washers right off the bolt.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now you're ready to tap! 👏
texts.text: Now you're ready to tap! 👏

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start in with the bolt holes in the rear and spray a decent amount of lubricant in the bottom and top of the bolt hole. Get your tap into the T-Handle wrench and slowly start turning it in the bolt hole like you were installing one of the bolts.
texts.text: Start in with the bolt holes in the rear and spray a decent amount of lubricant in the bottom and top of the bolt hole. Get your tap into the T-Handle wrench and slowly start turning it in the bolt hole like you were installing one of the bolts.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🛑  When you hit resistance, only go 1/2 to 1 turn further. Then back up 2-3 turns. This means you've dislodged some metal fragments in the threads!
texts.text: 🛑  When you hit resistance, only go 1/2 to 1 turn further. Then back up 2-3 turns. This means you've dislodged some metal fragments in the threads!

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Working on one of the back holes 💪
texts.text: Working on one of the back holes 💪

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: tapping.jpg
texts.text: tapping.jpg

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After backing up a bit, keep screwing it in further until you hit more resistance. Only go 1/2 to 1 turn more, then back out 2-3 turns. Keep doing this until your tap shows up out of the top side of the bolt hole.
texts.text: After backing up a bit, keep screwing it in further until you hit more resistance. Only go 1/2 to 1 turn more, then back out 2-3 turns. Keep doing this until your tap shows up out of the top side of the bolt hole.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With your tap sticking out of the top of the hole, grab a shop towel or paper towel and clear all of the metal filings away from the top of the hole. Then back the tap all the way out and clean your tap screw. It's likely going to be covered in black shavings.
texts.text: With your tap sticking out of the top of the hole, grab a shop towel or paper towel and clear all of the metal filings away from the top of the hole. Then back the tap all the way out and clean your tap screw. It's likely going to be covered in black shavings.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you want to be really thorough, lubricate the hole once more and keep working the tap until the threads feel really smooth. I added some lubricant and fed a  new bolt  in through the top  using finger strength only  until I knew the threads were clear.
texts.text: If you want to be really thorough, lubricate the hole once more and keep working the tap until the threads feel really smooth. I added some lubricant and fed a  new bolt  in through the top  using finger strength only  until I knew the threads were clear.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can test feed a  new bolt  through the bottom to verify that you've done a good job. Don't use the old bolts for this. You'll just get more junk in the threads again. 😭
texts.text: You can test feed a  new bolt  through the bottom to verify that you've done a good job. Don't use the old bolts for this. You'll just get more junk in the threads again. 😭

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Repeat these steps for the other four holes and you should be all set.
texts.text: Repeat these steps for the other four holes and you should be all set.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Replace the skid plate
texts.text: Replace the skid plate

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be sure to discard the old bolts to avoid causing more problems for yourself. Re-assemble the new front bolts with the spacer and retaining washer just like they were when you took the skid plate down.
texts.text: Be sure to discard the old bolts to avoid causing more problems for yourself. Re-assemble the new front bolts with the spacer and retaining washer just like they were when you took the skid plate down.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Get the back bolts going in first and get them in about halfway. Start working on the front bolts after that.
texts.text: Get the back bolts going in first and get them in about halfway. Start working on the front bolts after that.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When all four bolts are in, grab your torque wrench and tighten them to  22 ft/lbs or 30 Nm  as specified in the  manual :
texts.text: When all four bolts are in, grab your torque wrench and tighten them to  22 ft/lbs or 30 Nm  as specified in the  manual :

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Always check the instructions for torque specs! 🔧
texts.text: Always check the instructions for torque specs! 🔧

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: skid-plate-torque.png
texts.text: skid-plate-torque.png

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you don't own a torque wrench, I wouldn't tighten them much past finger tight with a socket wrench. Then drive to the hardware store and get a basic torque wrench. 😜
texts.text: If you don't own a torque wrench, I wouldn't tighten them much past finger tight with a socket wrench. Then drive to the hardware store and get a basic torque wrench. 😜

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Prevention
texts.text: Prevention

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is easy but annoying:  always remove the skid plate yourself before any kind of maintenance trip.
texts.text: This is easy but annoying:  always remove the skid plate yourself before any kind of maintenance trip.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Yes, this sounds silly, but these mount points are finicky and there's no guarantee that the dreaded impact wrench will not show up again to ruin your bolts. I remove mine before any oil changes or scheduled maintenance at the dealer.
texts.text: Yes, this sounds silly, but these mount points are finicky and there's no guarantee that the dreaded impact wrench will not show up again to ruin your bolts. I remove mine before any oil changes or scheduled maintenance at the dealer.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Dealers have asked me in the past "Where's your skid plate anyway?" and I let them know I don't want my bolts stripped. 😅
texts.text: Dealers have asked me in the past "Where's your skid plate anyway?" and I let them know I don't want my bolts stripped. 😅
